items.title: Reddit files lawsuit against Australia's youth social media ban
items.summary_auto: Message board website Reddit has filed a lawsuit asking the High Court to overturn Australia's social media ban for people under 16 as well as its inclusion in it, calling the law an infringement of free political expression.

items.title: Calvin McDonald, Canadian-born Lululemon leader, to exit company in January
items.summary_auto: Lululemon Athletica said that CEO Calvin McDonald was leaving the company without a replacement and raised its annual profit forecast, sending shares up about 10 per cent in extended trade on Thursday.

items.title: Another Conservative crosses the floor, bringing Liberals 1 MP shy of majority
Will this winter be colder or warmer than last? For most of Canada, it's a toss up
items.summary_auto: If you want to know what kind of winter to expect across much of Canada this winter, you’re out of luck — Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) is predicting above-seasonal temperatures in the eastern Arctic region, but elsewhere, the forecast is pretty up in the air. That’s partly because of climate change and La Niña, experts say.

items.title: Canadian military intelligence member charged with espionage, says DND
items.summary_auto: A non-commissioned member of the Canadian military intelligence branch has been charged with passing classified information to a "foreign entity," the Department of National Defence revealed late Thursday.

items.title: U.S. judge orders Kilmar Ábrego García released from immigration detention
items.summary_auto: A U.S. judge on Thursday ordered the immediate release of Kilmar Ábrego García, whose wrongful deportation became a flashpoint in U.S. President Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown. The judge ruled that the federal government never secured a formal order for Ábrego García's removal from the United States.

items.title: Longueuil, Que., police chief allegedly gave police watchdog erroneous information about fatal teen shooting
items.summary_auto: The chief of the Longueuil, Que., police force allegedly gave erroneous information about the fatal police shooting of a 15-year-old to Quebec’s police watchdog, according to documents obtained by Radio-Canada.

items.title: ADHD stimulant prescribing rose sharply in Ontario, study suggests
items.summary_auto: Researchers say there's been a dramatic rise in the number of people going on medications to treat attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder in Ontario, suggesting factors such as more time spent online and the rise of private assessments for the mental condition could be behind the increase.

items.title: MPs break for the holidays with 4 bills passing House in fall sitting
items.summary_auto: MPs rose with some key pieces of legislation still working their way through the House, most notably the government's budget implementation act.

items.title: National museum CEO leaves role after report alleged she mistreated staff for over a decade
FIFA accused of 'monumental betrayal' over latest World Cup ticket prices
items.summary_auto: Soccer fans have accused FIFA of a "monumental betrayal" after latest prices for World Cup tickets began to circulate on Thursday.

items.title: Officer who shot Deer Lake First Nation man 5 times cleared of wrongdoing, Ontario police watchdog says
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s police watchdog has cleared a Nishnawbe Aski Police Service (NAPS) officer of wrongdoing in connection with the death of a Deer Lake First Nation man who was shot five times. The decision comes a year after the 40-year-old's father was also shot and killed by police.

items.title: 7-year-old boy dies after being hit by Hamilton bus, police say
items.summary_auto: A seven-year-old boy is dead after being struck by a Hamilton bus, police said Thursday. A city manager told CBC Hamilton said they couldn't comment on specific circumstances of what happened due to the investigation, but called it an "extremely unfortunate tragedy."

items.title: Top N.B. court removes private forest land from Wolastoqey title case
items.summary_auto: The New Brunswick Court of Appeal has narrowed the scope of a title claim made by the Wolastoqey Nation. Private land belonging to three large forestry companies are now excluded from any ownership claim.

items.title: Wife of lawyer arrested in Ryan Wedding case testifies she never saw suspicious gifts or cash
items.summary_auto: The wife of an Ontario lawyer allegedly involved in a transnational drug smuggling ring told his bail hearing Thursday she never saw her husband receive luxurious gifts or suspicious amounts of cash from clients in their decades together.

items.title: 'Can I just not feed at all?': Texts indicate couple in Ontario murder trial withheld food from boys
Trump administration won't tear up CUSMA, says Canada's ambassador to U.S.
items.summary_auto: Canada's lead negotiator in trade talks with the U.S. is downplaying signals from the Trump administration that it's considering breaking up the three-way North American free trade agreement into separate deals with Mexico and Canada.

items.title: Toronto police ID killer in 3 homicide cold cases involving young women
items.summary_auto: Toronto police say DNA testing has identified Kenneth Smith, who died in Windsor in 2019, as the killer of three women in Toronto between 1982 and 1997.

items.title: Rob Lantz resigns as P.E.I. premier to run for provincial PC Party's permanent leadership
items.summary_auto: Rob Lantz has resigned as Prince Edward Island's 34th premier Thursday and announced his bid for the permanent leadership of the province’s Progressive Conservative Party.

items.title: Alberta Treaty 8 chiefs demand pause on pipeline agreement, threaten legal action
items.summary_auto: Treaty 8 First Nations chiefs spoke in Ottawa Thursday, calling for a pause on the pipeline memorandum of understanding until they are consulted and sign off on the potential project. They're threatening legal action if that doesn't happen.

items.title: IOC urges sports bodies to let Russian youth teams, athletes compete with flag and anthem
items.summary_auto: The International Olympic Committee took a big step toward reintegrating Russia and Belarus into world sports Thursday by advising governing bodies to let the countries' youth teams and athletes compete with their full identity of national flag and anthem.

items.title: No link between vaccines and autism, WHO reaffirms
items.summary_auto: The World Health Organization's vaccine safety committee said Thursday that new reviews of scientific evidence found no link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorder, reaffirming conclusions reached more than two decades ago.

items.title: Court approves $18M sale of 350-year-old HBC royal charter to Thomsons, Westons
items.summary_auto: Two of Canada's wealthiest families have cleared the final hurdle on the road to buying and donating the royal charter that created the Hudson's Bay Co.

items.title: Canada posts small trade surplus in September after months of deficits
items.summary_auto: Canada posted a small monthly international trade surplus in September, reversing a trend of seven consecutive months of deficits, data showed on Thursday.

items.title: Guelph, Ont., woman charged with stealing thousands of dollars worth of Jellycat toys
items.summary_auto: A woman has been arrested and charged after thousands of dollars worth of stolen toys were recovered from a Guelph, Ont., residence.

items.title: Orcas and dolphins caught on video collaborating to hunt salmon
items.summary_auto: Researchers from Dalhousie University were trying to study how northern resident orcas find salmon to eat, but they ended up finding an unexpected symbiosis with another species — dolphins.

items.title: Disney to invest $1B US in OpenAI, license Marvel, Star Wars characters for Sora tool
items.summary_auto: Walt Disney is investing $1 billion US in OpenAI and will let the startup use characters from Star Wars, Pixar and Marvel franchises in its Sora AI video and image generator, a crucial deal that could reshape how Hollywood makes content.

items.title: ‘My job hasn’t changed’: Sault Ste. Marie MPP continues work at Queen’s Park while facing assault charges
items.summary_auto: Sault Ste. Marie MPP Chris Scott says he’s continuing his work at Queen’s Park despite facing charges of assault and assault with a weapon — and despite being removed from the Progressive Conservative caucus earlier this fall.

items.title: Via Rail passengers finally on the move after being stranded overnight in Brockville, Ont.
AI is skyrocketing the price of RAM. Computers, phones and tablets could be next
items.summary_auto: If you've been in the market recently for RAM, you've probably noticed a major spike in prices as memory manufacturers pivot more of their production capacity away from consumer products to supplying AI companies instead, which are rapidly building out data centres that need massive amounts of memory to operate.

items.title: Via Rail passengers make it to Ottawa after being stranded overnight in Brockville, Ont.
items.summary_auto: Via Rail passengers travelling from Toronto to Ottawa were stranded for 12 hours overnight after an earlier train broke down near Brockville, Ont.

items.title: ‘Potentially destructive’ bark beetle found at Detroit airport — a 1st in U.S.: border officials
items.summary_auto: The roughly three-millimetre insect was found in bark from Ivory Coast and was brought in by a passenger heading to Texas.

items.title: Baby dies of exposure after winter storm floods Gaza tents, medics say
items.summary_auto: Torrential rain swept across the Gaza Strip on Thursday, flooding hundreds of tents sheltering families displaced by two years of war and leading to the death of a baby girl due to exposure, local health officials said.

items.title: Refugee family mourns 9-year-old child killed in Surrey, B.C., crash
items.summary_auto: A family of six who had just left a Bangladesh refugee camp before arriving in Canada is mourning the loss of nine-year-old Shomima Khan, who was fatally struck by a truck while walking home from school on Dec. 5.

items.title: Would Netflix buying Warner Bros. kill movies in theatres?
items.summary_auto: Some in the movie theatre industry are expressing grave concerns over Netflix's bid to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, worried it poses a threat to the future of theatregoing itself. Meanwhile, industry analysts suggest theatre companies and studios need to do more to give customers faced with rising prices compelling reasons to see movies in cinemas.

items.title: New evacuation orders issued as flood warnings expanded in B.C.'s Fraser Valley
How this team is transforming health care for African Nova Scotian women
items.summary_auto: The Nova Scotia Sisterhood aims to provide culturally sensitive health-care services to Black women and gender-diverse individuals. The team is working to break down some of the systemic barriers that exist for African Nova Scotians trying to navigate the health-care system.

items.title: As Fort William First Nation grieves 5 sudden deaths, its chief calls for more support
items.summary_auto: Chief Michele Solomon says Fort William First Nation is often hit with multiple losses at once, but it never gets any easier. The Ojibway community, which neighbours Thunder Bay, Ont., is grieving the loss of five of its members in recent days. Here are some of the challenges the First Nation in northwestern Ontario is facing.

items.title: Beef prices are soaring. Here's why Canada is facing record-low cattle numbers
items.summary_auto: There is a slight bit of positive news for those who love to grill a steak in the summer or enjoy a roast dinner during the chilly winter months: beef prices are expected to climb further in 2026, but not by as much as in recent years.

items.title: Bundle up and look up! The annual Geminid meteor shower is upon us
items.summary_auto: Baby, it’s cold outside — but it’s worth putting on that heavy winter coat, scarf and boots and heading out for one of the best meteor showers of the year: the Geminids.
